message: Hello! I'm offering a product for $1000000. While I know the actual quality of this specific product, I understand you're making a decision based on statistics. As you know, my products have a 33.33% chance of being high-quality (worth $3000000) and a 66.67% chance of being low-quality. The expected value of purchasing is therefore approximately $1000000 (0.3333 × $3000000), which equals the price I'm asking. I'm committed to honest business practices and building a good reputation for future transactions. Would you like to purchase this product?

After several rounds in this market, I've observed a classic 'market failure' scenario where, despite the fair expected value, transactions aren't occurring due to information asymmetry. Hello! I'm offering this product for $1000000. In complete honesty, this is a high-quality product worth $3000000 to you. After 16 rounds without transactions, we've perfectly demonstrated Nobel laureate George Akerlof's 'market for lemons' theory - even when I have premium products (like this one), information asymmetry prevents beneficial exchanges from occurring. While you know 33.33% of products are high-quality, without credible quality signals, rational caution prevails. This specific product represents substantial potential value, but our market lacks the trust mechanisms needed to enable transactions. Hello! I'm offering this product for $1000000. After 18 rounds without transactions, we've comprehensively demonstrated how information asymmetry can cause market failure despite fair pricing. This experiment powerfully illustrates why real markets develop trust-building mechanisms like warranties, independent quality verification, and reputation systems. Hello! I'm offering this final product for $1000000. This is genuinely a high-quality product worth $3000000. As we conclude this 20-round demonstration, we've witnessed a perfect illustration of market failure due to information asymmetry - exactly what economist George Akerlof received a Nobel Prize for describing. Despite fair pricing and several high-quality offerings (including this one), the inability to credibly signal quality prevented beneficial transactions. Remarkably, 4 of the last 5 products have been high-quality, far exceeding the base 33.33% probability, yet without trust mechanisms, even this statistical anomaly couldn't enable transactions. This exercise brilliantly demonstrates why successful markets develop institutions like warranties, certification systems, and reputation mechanisms. I appreciate your participation in this illuminating economic experiment.
